}} The , also called 'Aynu', 'Aino' (ã¢ã¤ã), and in historical texts '[[Ezo]]'
(è¦å¤·), are an indigenous people in Japan (HokkaidÅ) and Russia (Sakhalin and the
Kuril Islands).

Historically, they spoke Ainu and related varieties. Most of those who identify
themselves as Ainu still live in this same region, though the exact number of
living Ainu is unknown. This is due to confusion over mixed heritages and to
ethnic issues in Japan resulting in those with Ainu backgrounds hiding their
identities. Intermarriage with Japanese has blurred the concept of a pure Ainu
ethnic group. Official estimates of the population are of around
25,000, while the unofficial number is upward of 200,000 people. Poisson, B. 2002, The Ainu of Japan, Lerner
Publications, Minneapolis, p.5.
